title: Hot Liquid Scalds
summary: Immediate care for burns caused by hot liquids like water, coffee, soup, or steam, especially common in kitchen accidents.

steps.title: Remove From Heat Source
steps.description: Move the person away from the hot liquid source immediately. Turn off heat sources if safe to do so. Be careful of slippery surfaces from spilled liquids.

steps.title: Cool the Burn Immediately
steps.description: Run cool (not ice cold) water over the burned area for 10-20 minutes. This must be done within the first 20 minutes after injury to be effective. If running water isn't available, immerse in cool water or apply cool, wet cloths.

steps.title: Remove Clothing and Jewelry
steps.description: Quickly and gently remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area before swelling begins. If clothing is stuck to the burn, do not pull it off - cut around it. Remove rings, watches, and belts.

steps.title: Assess Burn Severity
steps.description: Check the size and depth of the burn. First-degree: red, painful, no blisters. Second-degree: blisters, severe pain, red and splotchy. Third-degree: white or charred, may be painless due to nerve damage.

steps.title: Cover the Burn
steps.description: After cooling, cover the burn with a sterile, non-adhesive dressing or clean cloth. Do not use fluffy cotton or material that may stick. Wrap loosely to avoid pressure. Do not apply creams, butter, or ice.

steps.title: Manage Pain and Monitor
steps.description: Give over-the-counter pain relief if needed. Elevate burned arms or legs. Watch for signs of shock. For facial burns, monitor breathing. Keep the person warm with blankets over unburned areas.

warnings: Never use ice directly on burns - it can cause tissue damage
Do not break blisters - they protect against infection
Avoid home remedies like butter, oil, or toothpaste
Scalds can be deeper than they initially appear
whenToSeekHelp: Burns larger than 3 inches or covering joints
Burns on face, hands, feet, genitals, or major joints
Burns in children under 5 or adults over 60
Burns that circle around a limb
Signs of infection: increased pain, pus, fever
preventionTips: Set water heater temperature to 120°F (49°C) or below
Turn pot handles toward the center of the stove
Keep hot liquids away from table and counter edges
Test bath water before placing children in tub
Use splash guards when cooking with hot oil
